text:
Corbyn's leadership 'reboot' in disarray amid major U-turns on immigration policy and salary cap proposal Watch | The Corbyn market: Jeremy's post-Brexit vision for Britain 01:34 Steven Swinford , Deputy Political Editor 10 January 2017 • 10:00pm 
L abour's immigration policy was in chaos on Tuesday night after Jeremy Corbyn reversed his position on free movement just hours after suggesting his party would oppose uncontrolled migration to the UK. 
Mr Corbyn had indicated on Monday that he was prepared to address the concerns of Labour voters by announcing that his party was "not wedded" to free movement and favoured "reasonably managed migration". 
However when he delivered his speech on Tuesday the Labour leader changed a key paragraph to say that the party did not "rule out" keeping free movement in exchange for access to the Single Market. Credit: Christian Adams for The Telegraph 
I n a second major policy u-turn the Labour leader announced his support for a "maximum earnings" limit on Tuesday morning only to abandon the policy just hours after proposing it. 
He backtracked on the plans just hours later after they were dismissed by his own former economic adviser as a "lunatic idea" and "completely unworkable". 
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn said that he "mispoke" and the Labour leader later called instead for executives at companies with Government contracts to be limited to earning 20 times more than their most junior staff. 
The Labour leader also called for a new top rate of income tax for those earning above £70,000, claiming it would make society fairer. Watch | Hundreds queue for buses amid tube strike 00:36 
H e also enraged commuters by saying he would be ready to join the rail unions on the picket lines as more than 300,000 workers were hit by strike action. 
One shadow minister said that the series of u-turns and new policy announcements had been "disastrous". The shadow minister said: "There's no doubt about it, today has looked like a disaster. 
"Within a day we've been forced to backtrack on a surprise call fro the leader to cap the wages of high-earners and the suggestion we were actually taking a tougher line on free movement." 
Stephen Kinnock, a Labour MP who has called for greater controls, said: "These mixed messages are deeply corrosive to our standing in the country. If we want to be a credible opposition we have got to have clarity. "I think that it really is time for Jeremy to level with the British people, it is frustrating that we haven't managed to clarify the position today." 
Mr Corbyn's speech on Tuesday afternoon had been intended to end the confusion surrounding his stance on migration after bitter clashes with his shadow cabinet. 
Tom Watson, Labour's deputy leader, admitted at the weekend that the party does not have a position and said that Jeremy Corbyn must address the concerns of voters calling for migration curbs. Watch | Corbyn: There's no sea change on freedom of movement 02:04 
H owever in a series of interviews on Tuesday morning he said that he was not willing to put limits on migration, and suggested he was prepared to accept free movement in return for access to the Single Market. 
"If the EU says access to the single market requires freedom of movement, I would say... economically we've got to be able to trade with Europe," Mr Corbyn told ITV's Good Morning Britain. 
Asked on BBC Radio 4's Today programme whether he had a number in mind for what level of immigration would be acceptable, Mr Corbyn said: "I am not putting a figure on it." 
When he delivered his speech in Peterborough on Tuesday afternoon, he added a significant caveat. "Labour is not wedded to freedom of movement for EU citizens as a point of principle, but I don’t want that to be misinterpreted, nor do we rule it out," he said. Watch | Jeremy Corbyn 'reboot' fails as he calls for high-earnings cap 00:42 
M r Corbyn added to the chaos by calling for a Cuba-style maximum wage, adding that it would be "somewhat higher" than the £138,000 he earns. 
He suggested it could apply to football players and company executives. He said: "I think, certainly, the salaries that are paid to some footballers are simply ridiculous. I think some of the salaries paid to very high-earning top executives of companies are utterly ridiculous." 
He said other countries had developed policies on a maximum wage. However, the only state thought to have one in force is Cuba – where it has been set at 20 US dollars a month. Watch | Corbyn ditches wage caps in favour of ratios of pay 01:33 
H owever Danny Blanchflower, a former adviser to the Labour leader and member of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee, said that the idea was "completely unworkable". 
He said on Twitter: "Corbyn max wage lunatic idea would generate a huge brain drain as smart people move abroad shows how out of touch he is," he wrote on Twitter. Corbyn max wage idea idiotic firms would simply pay workers by giving profit shares — Danny Blanchflower (@D_Blanchflower) January 10, 2017 
P atrick McLoughlin, the chairman of the Conservative Party, said: “Jeremy Corbyn’s day has gone from bad to worse - with his ‘relaunch’ descending further into chaos. 
“Today he showed that Labour simply will not take control over immigration, by saying that he ‘doesn’t rule out’ keeping freedom of movement. 
"He suggested a new 100 per cent tax rate, which he u-turned on within hours. And he told hard-pressed commuters affected by strikes that he would stand on the picket lines with the union bosses making their lives a misery. 
"Labour simply could not be more out of touch with ordinary working people.”
